definitionsEn: Feeling or showing pleasure or contentment
examplesEn: I'm so happy to see you!
usageNotes: Use 'happy about something' or 'happy to do something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'happy with' when you mean 'happy about'. Use 'happy with' for satisfaction with a person or thing.

examplesEn: I feel sad when I think about leaving.
She gave me a sad smile.
usageNotes: Can describe temporary feelings or longer emotional states.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'sad' to describe bad situations - use 'unfortunate' or 'terrible' instead.

definitionsEn: Feeling or showing strong annoyance, displeasure, or hostility
examplesEn: He was angry about the decision.
She gave me an angry look.
usageNotes: Use 'angry with someone' or 'angry about something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'angry at' - use 'angry with' (for people) or 'angry about' (for situations).

examplesEn: Health is more important than money.
He is an important person in the company.
usageNotes: Use 'it is important to do something' or 'it is important that...'
commonMistakes: Don't use 'very important' in formal writing - 'crucial' or 'essential' are better alternatives.

definitionsEn: Not the same as another or each other
usageNotes: Use 'different from' (most common), 'different to' (British), or 'different than' (American).
commonMistakes: Don't say 'different that' - use 'different from' or 'different than'.

definitionsEn: That might or may not happen
examplesEn: Is it possible to finish today?
It's possible that it will rain.
usageNotes: Use 'as soon as possible' or 'if possible' for common expressions.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'possible to do something' without 'it is' - say 'it is possible to do something'.

definitionsEn: Required to be done or obtained
examplesEn: It is necessary to study hard.
usageNotes: Stronger than 'needed' - implies something cannot be avoided.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'necessary' for simple preferences - use 'needed' or 'wanted' instead.

definitionsEn: As much or as many as needed
usageNotes: Can go before or after the noun: 'enough time' or 'time enough' (less common).
commonMistakes: Don't say 'enough hot' - say 'hot enough'. Adverbs come after the adjective.

definitionsEn: Able to be used or obtained
examplesEn: This room is available for rent.
usageNotes: Commonly used for appointments, resources, and products.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'available to buy' - say 'available for purchase' or just 'available'.

definitionsEn: Not easy to do or understand
examplesEn: It's difficult to learn a new language.
She is in a difficult situation.
usageNotes: More formal than 'hard'. Use in formal contexts.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'difficult' to describe people - use 'difficult person' is OK, but 'hard person' is not correct.

definitionsEn: Able to cause harm or injury
usageNotes: Use 'dangerous to someone' or 'dangerous for something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'very dangerous' when describing minor risks - 'risky' is more appropriate.

examplesEn: Are you interested in this job?
usageNotes: Always use 'interested in' (not 'at' or 'for').
commonMistakes: Don't say 'interested to' - always use 'interested in' or 'interested to learn' (for infinitive).

examplesEn: The children are excited about Christmas.
usageNotes: Use 'excited about something' or 'excited to do something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'excited with' - use 'excited about' or 'excited by'.

examplesEn: I'm worried about the exam results.
usageNotes: Use 'worried about someone/something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'worried for' - use 'worried about' in most cases.

definitionsEn: Feeling weary because of uninteresting activity
usageNotes: Use 'bored with something' or 'bored of doing something'.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'bored' (feeling) with 'boring' (causing boredom).

examplesEn: I was surprised by the news.
She seemed surprised to see me.
usageNotes: Use 'surprised by/at something' or 'surprised to do something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'surprised with' - use 'surprised by' or 'surprised at'.

definitionsEn: In need of rest or sleep
usageNotes: Use 'tired from something' (cause) or 'tired of something' (fed up).
commonMistakes: Don't say 'tired to do something' - use 'too tired to do something'.

usageNotes: Can describe physical comfort or emotional ease.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'comfortable to do something' - use 'comfortable doing something'.

usageNotes: Use 'successful in/at something' or 'successful at doing something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'success' when you mean 'successful' - 'success' is the noun.

examplesEn: He became famous for his paintings.
usageNotes: Use 'famous for something' when stating what someone is known for.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'famous by' - use 'famous for' to indicate the reason.

usageNotes: Use 'ready for something' or 'ready to do something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'ready with' unless referring to having something prepared.

definitionsEn: Having no doubt that something is true
examplesEn: Are you sure you want to go?
Make sure to lock the door.
usageNotes: Use 'sure of/about something' or 'sure to do something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'sure that' in formal English - use 'sure whether' or 'sure if'.

examplesEn: Don't be afraid of the dark.
I'm afraid I can't help you.
usageNotes: Use 'afraid of something/someone' or 'afraid to do something'.
commonMistakes: Use 'I'm afraid' as a polite way to say no or give bad news.

examplesEn: She is proud of her work.
You should be proud of yourself.
usageNotes: Always use 'proud of' someone or something.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'proud with' or 'proud about' - always 'proud of'.

examplesEn: He is jealous of his brother.
usageNotes: Use 'jealous of someone/something'. Can be negative (envious) or protective.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'envious' - 'jealous' is stronger and can be about relationships.

definitionsEn: Resembling something but not the same
examplesEn: She looks similar to her mother.
usageNotes: Use 'similar to' (not 'with' or 'from').
commonMistakes: Don't say 'similar with' - use 'similar to' or 'similar in'.

definitionsEn: Liked or admired by many people
usageNotes: Use 'popular with someone' or 'popular among people'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'popular by' - use 'popular with' or 'popular among'.

usageNotes: Refers to something available to everyone, not private.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'pub' (short for public house - a bar).

examplesEn: I need to speak with you in private.
usageNotes: Can mean not public, personal, or confidential.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'privacy' (noun) when you mean 'private' (adjective).

usageNotes: Often refers to one's immediate area or community.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'local' to mean 'traditional' - that's a different meaning.

usageNotes: Can refer to other countries or things unfamiliar to someone.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'foreign' to describe people - use 'from another country' instead.

examplesEn: The main entrance is over there.
usageNotes: Used to identify the most important thing in a group.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'main' to mean 'most' - they have different meanings.

usageNotes: Emphasizes size, importance, or seriousness.
commonMistakes: Can also be a noun meaning a university subject or military rank.

definitionsEn: Happening or beginning a short time ago
examplesEn: I read about it in recent news.
Have there been any recent changes?
examplesTr: Son zamanlarda bir değişiklik oldu mu?
usageNotes: Refers to things that happened not long ago.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'recent' for future events - only past or present.

examplesEn: They live in a modern apartment.
usageNotes: Often implies improvement over old ways.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'modern' to mean 'fashionable' - they're different concepts.

examplesEn: We have traditional food on holidays.
usageNotes: Refers to practices passed down through generations.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'historic' (important in history) - traditional is about customs.

definitionsEn: Relating to activities with other people
examplesEn: She has an active social life.
usageNotes: Can refer to society or interpersonal activities.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'social' to mean 'socialist' (political ideology).

examplesEn: Her political party won the election.
usageNotes: Refers to government, elections, and political activities.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'politics' (the subject) with 'political' (the adjective).

definitionsEn: Of or relating to a culture
examplesEn: She is interested in cultural activities.
The city is known for cultural diversity.
usageNotes: Refers to the arts, customs, and achievements of a society.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'cultural' to mean 'cultured' (having good manners/taste).

usageNotes: Used in business and personal money matters.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'finance' (noun) with 'financial' (adjective).

examplesEn: He works in a medical field.
usageNotes: Refers to health care, medicine, and treatment.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'medicine' (noun) when you mean 'medical' (adjective).

examplesEn: We have a legal right to protest.
examplesTr: Protest etmek için yasal hakkımız var.
usageNotes: Can mean 'permitted by law' or 'relating to law'.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse 'legal' with 'legible' (able to be read).

examplesEn: The view is beautiful and natural.
usageNotes: Can mean 'from nature' or 'normal/expected'.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'natural' to mean 'obvious' - that's a different meaning.

definitionsEn: Relating to things you can touch
usageNotes: Relates to the body or material things (not mental).
commonMistakes: Don't use 'physical' to mean 'energetic' - though they can overlap.

usageNotes: Relates to the mind, not the body.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'mental' as an insult - it's a legitimate term for psychological matters.

usageNotes: Can mean relating to emotions or showing emotions.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'emotional' to mean 'dramatic' - they're related but different.

usageNotes: Can mean 'as a paid job' or 'showing expertise'.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'professional' to mean 'polite' - they're different.

usageNotes: Refers to something belonging to or affecting one person.
commonMistakes: The phrase is 'take it personally' (with -ly), not 'take it personal'.

usageNotes: Can mean optimistic/constructive or certain/definite.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'positive' when you mean 'good' - use 'positive' for attitude/thinking.

usageNotes: Can mean pessimistic in attitude or expressing disagreement.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with 'negotiative' (relating to negotiation).

definitionsEn: Showing things as they really are
usageNotes: Means both 'achievable' and 'true to reality'.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'realistic' to mean 'real' - realistic is about being practical/achievable.

examplesEn: I was careful not to make mistakes.
usageNotes: Use 'careful with something' or 'careful about something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'careful of' - use 'careful with' or 'careful about'.

definitionsEn: Feeling optimism about a future event
examplesEn: We are hopeful for a good result.
usageNotes: Use 'hopeful about something' or 'hopeful of something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'hopeful to' - use 'hopeful about' or 'hopeful of'.

examplesEn: She was nervous about the presentation.
usageNotes: Use 'nervous about something' or 'nervous of something'.
commonMistakes: Don't say 'nervous to do something' - use 'nervous about doing something'.

usageNotes: Can mean not joking, important, or severe/bad.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'serious' to mean 'sincere' - though they can overlap.

usageNotes: Can mean unusual, unfamiliar, or odd/bizarre.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'strange' to be rude about differences - use 'unusual' to be more polite.

usageNotes: Means completely without faults or exactly right.
commonMistakes: The verb is pronounced /pərˈfekt/ (per-FECT), the adjective is /ˈpɜːrfɪkt/ (PER-fect).

usageNotes: Stronger than 'good' or 'very good'.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'excellent' for casual things - 'great' or 'really good' are more common.

usageNotes: Stronger than 'bad' or 'very bad'.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'terrible' to describe minor problems - 'bad' is sufficient.

usageNotes: Can mean very bad quality or very unpleasant feeling.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'awful' to mean 'full of awe' (respectful wonder) - that's 'awesome'.

usageNotes: Stronger than 'good' - expresses enthusiasm and delight.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'wonderful' for ordinary things - 'nice' or 'good' are more appropriate.

usageNotes: Can mean extraordinarily good or imaginative/unreal.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'fantastic' in very formal writing - 'excellent' or 'outstanding' are better.

usageNotes: Stronger than 'good' or 'great' - implies surprise.
commonMistakes: Don't overuse 'amazing' - it loses impact when used for everything.

usageNotes: Can mean literally unbelievable or figuratively wonderful.
commonMistakes: Don't use 'incredible' for formal reports - 'remarkable' or 'exceptional' are better.
